Lorraine, of course I know you as part of what we informally know as the Burley Girls, very much part of the Cardiff Ballest scene.
How did you first come across Cardiff Carnival?
Well it's part of a yearly event, we always go to the carnival and then we were very very pleased to be asked would we perform once again.
So of course we all jump at the chance because it's another opportunity to dress up and perform.
One of our shows was called Flying Down to Rio.
So we needed the help and assistance from you guys at Swicker and obviously Adrian is such a whiz with the glue gun and the glitter and wire and everything.
And we needed to know how to make our headdresses for our showgirl costumes and our cage bras.
So we came along to many sessions and the end result, obviously if you go on the page you'll see it, but the end result we just made the most fabulous costumes.
And sequins, feathers, braiding, everything and we shone and sparkled.
And then obviously we performed at the actual carnival itself and we did a few numbers and then we paraded.
What was the audience reaction like to see these wonderful Samba showgirls, Burley style, in the centre of Cardiff?
I think they were transported and I think they absolutely thought that's carnival.
That's what a carnival should have. And we delivered.
